title: CN Level 10 — Secure Web App Networking
concept: End-to-end design of a secure web application deployment: segmentation, HTTPS, firewalls.

challenges.title: Q1: Secure Deployment Architecture
challenges.description: Design a high-level network architecture for hosting a secure web application. Include components like load balancer, web/app servers, database, and indicate which parts are exposed to the Internet and which are in private networks.
challenges.outputDescription: Diagram-style text description of public vs private segments (checked manually).
examples: Think of: Internet → load balancer in public subnet → app servers in private subnet → DB in deeper private subnet (no direct Internet access).
challenges.starterCode: // Describe the components, their placement (public/private), and basic data flow.

challenges.title: Q2: HTTPS & Firewall Rules
challenges.description: Explain how HTTPS and firewall rules help secure the web application in the above architecture. Mention what traffic is allowed from the Internet and what is restricted between subnets.
challenges.outputDescription: Explanation of TLS for encryption and firewall rules for access control (checked manually).
examples: Example: Allow HTTPS (443) from Internet to load balancer only, allow app servers to talk to DB on specific port from specific subnet, deny all else.
challenges.starterCode: // Describe how HTTPS protects data in transit and how firewall rules restrict access.

challenges.title: Q3: DMZ Concept
challenges.description: Define what a DMZ (demilitarized zone) is in network security and explain where in your web app architecture you would place it.
challenges.outputDescription: Short explanation and placement of DMZ.
examples: Hint: Public-facing servers (like reverse proxy/load balancer) often live in a DMZ between external and internal networks.
challenges.starterCode: // Define DMZ and explain which components should be placed there.

challenges.title: Q4: Logging and Monitoring
challenges.description: Describe at least three types of logs or monitoring metrics you would enable to detect security incidents or performance issues in this web app environment.
challenges.outputDescription: List and explanation of metrics/logs (manual evaluation).
examples: Examples: Web server access logs, firewall logs, IDS/IPS alerts, CPU/memory usage, error rates, unusual login attempts.
challenges.starterCode: // List logs/metrics and briefly explain why each is useful.

challenges.title: Q5: Least Privilege Principle
challenges.description: Explain the principle of least privilege and give two examples of how you would apply it in the secure web application network design.
examples: Example: DB user account with only required permissions; firewall allowing only necessary ports between specific hosts.
challenges.starterCode: // Explain the principle and give at least two concrete implementations.
